Fig. 1 (A) Buchwald-Hartwig C–N cross-coupling. (B) Well-defined, air-stable acenaphthoquinone chloro dimer N-heterocyclic carbene catalyst platform, palladium–BIAN–NHC, [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2. Fig. 2 Kinetic profile of the Buchwald-Hartwig cross-coupling catalyzed by [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 and [Pd(IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2. Conditions: [Pd(NHC)Cl2]2 (0.5 mol%), 4-Tol-Cl (1.0 equiv), 4-Tol-NH2 (2.0 equiv), CH3OK (3.0 equiv), toluene (0.5 M), 120 °C, 0–60 min, Argon or air. Scheme 1 Scope of the Buchwald-Hartwig cross-coupling catalyzed by [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2. Conditions: ArX (1.0 equiv), amine (2.0 equiv), [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), CH3OK (3.0 equiv), toluene (0.5 M), 120 °C, 8 h. Scheme 2 Scope of the Buchwald-Hartwig cross-coupling catalyzed by [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2. Conditions: ArX (1.0 equiv), morpholine (2.0 equiv), [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), CH3OK (3.0 equiv), toluene (0.5 M), 120 °C, 8 h. Scheme 3 Scope of the Buchwald-Hartwig cross-coupling catalyzed by [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2. Conditions: 4-Chlorotoluene (1.0 equiv), amine (2.0 equiv), [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), CH3OK (3.0 equiv), toluene (0.5 M), 120 °C, 8 h. Scheme 4 Applications of the Buchwald-Hartwig cross-coupling catalyzed by [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2. Conditions: ArX (1.0 equiv), amine (2.0 equiv), [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (1.0 mol%), CH3OK (3.0 equiv), toluene (0.5 M), 120 °C, 8 h. Scheme 5 Competition studies. Conditions: A. chlorobenzene (2.0 equiv each), morpholine (1 equiv), CH3OK (3 equiv), [Pd(BIAN-IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), toluene (0.5 M), 120 ℃, Ar, 8 h. B. aniline (2.0 equiv each), 1-chloro-4-methylbenzene (1 equiv), CH3OK (3 equiv), [Pd(BIAN-IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), toluene (0.5 M), 120 ℃, Ar, 8 h. Scheme 6 Determination of the TON number. Conditions: chlorobenzene (1.0 equiv each), aniline (2 equiv), CH3OK (3 equiv), [Pd(BIAN-IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.025–0.0125 mol%), toluene (0.5 M), 120 ℃, Ar, 8 h. Scheme 7 Comparative studies with [Pd(NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 congener: scope of aryl halide. Conditions: aryl halide (1.0 equiv), morpholine (2 equiv), CH3OK (3 equiv), [Pd(NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), toluene (0.5 M), 120 ℃, Ar, 8 h. Scheme 8 Comparative studies with [Pd(NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 congener: scope of amine. Conditions: 4-Chlorotoluene (1.0 equiv), amine (2 equiv), CH3OK (3 equiv), [Pd(NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), toluene (0.5 M), 120 ℃, Ar, 8 h. Warren Street, Newark, NJ 07102, United States Graphical abstract Buchwald-Hartwig amination has become the fundamental method for constructing molecular architectures throughout chemical research, including the synthesis of pharmaceutical agents, natural products, fine chemicals, and advanced materials. Herein, we report air-stable, well-defined palladium–BIAN–NHC chloro dimer, [Pd(BIAN–NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, for Buchwald-Hartwig C–N cross-coupling reactions of aryl halides. This rapidly activating catalyst framework merges the reactive properties of palladium chloro dimers, [Pd(NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, with the structural features of acenaphthoimidazol-2-ylidenes. [Pd(BIAN–NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 is the most reactive Pd(II)–NHC precatalyst to date, undergoing fast activation under both inert atmosphere and aerobic conditions. The catalyst shows an excellent reactivity in Buchwald-Hartwig amination of aryl halides (59 examples), including challenging substrates, diamination and direct functionalization of pharmaceuticals. The steric protection enables high reactivity under both inert atmosphere and aerobic conditions. [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 should be routinely utilized for the synthesis of C–N bonds to make valuable amines, where it replaces the most commonly deployed at present IPr (IPr = 1,3-bis(2,6-isopropyl)imidazol-2-ylidene). Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Palladium-catalyzed Buchwald-Hartwig amination has become the most valuable method for the synthesis of C–N bonds in organic synthesis. At present, Buchwald-Hartwig amination is the method of choice for the generation of molecular architectures throughout organic synthesis, including drug discovery, natural product synthesis, fine chemicals, and materials science (Fig. 1 A) [1–4]. In particular, amines represent the most prevalent functional group in pharmaceutical discovery, where the development of Buchwald-Hartwig amination reactions has revolutionized the discovery of new molecular frameworks through modular C–N bond formation. The extraordinary success of this C–N bond cross-coupling has singularly relied on the development of new ligand classes [5]. In particular, N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) represent a highly attractive class of ligands for Buchwald-Hartwig amination reactions owing to the flexible sterics around the metal center enabled by an umbrella-type N-wingtip arrangement and strong σ-donation of carbene centers [6,7]. However, the most commonly employed NHC ligand, IPr (IPr = 1,3-bis(2,6-isopropyl)imidazol-2-ylidene) suffers from the limited steric hindrance around the metal center. In this catalysis platform, well-defined Pd(II)–NHC catalysts are most attractive because they enable to use reactive Pd–carbene complexes in an optimal 1:1 ligand:metal ratio under highly practical reaction conditions, while undergoing facile activation to monoligated Pd(0)–NHCs. The most successful to date are [Pd(IPr)(allyl)Cl] complexes, which are now commercially available in different variations from several suppliers and have been routinely deployed in a variety of cross-coupling processes [8] However, recent studies clearly demonstrate that palladium chloro dimers [9], [Pd(IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, are strongly preferred class of precatalysts due to fast dimer dissociation combined with facile activation to form monoligated Pd(0)–NHCs and the avoidance of the inactive off-cycle Pd(I)–allyls, which are formed from [Pd(IPr)(allyl)Cl] complexes and lead to unproductive catalyst decomposition [10]. Simultaneously, major progress has been made in acenaphthoimidazol-2-ylidene (BIAN = bis(imino) acenaphtene) complexes.[11] This structural architecture permits to move N-wingtip substituents towards the metal, which results in a significantly precise control of the catalytic pocket during the elementary steps (cf. simple imidazol-2-ylidenes, such as IPr) and an increased protection of the metal center during the cross-coupling. The bulky-yet-flexible sterics of BIAN–IPr in combination with strong σ-donation provide a particularly attractive catalyst platform for organic synthesis that is difficult to achieve with the classical imidazol-2-ylidene catalysts. Recently, as a part of our program in NHC ligands and catalysis,[12] we developed a merger of the BIAN–IPr framework with the rapidly dissociating palladium chloro dimers for Suzuki biaryl cross-coupling.[13] Consideration the critical role of Buchwald-Hartwig amination reactions in all fields of of chemical research, we investigated the reactivity of this catalyst platform in arguably the most critical C–N bond formation in chemical synthesis. Herein, we report air-stable, well-defined palladium–BIAN–NHC chloro dimer catalyst platform for Buchwald-Hartwig C–N cross-coupling reactions of aryl halides. Pd(BIAN–NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 is the most reactive Pd(II)–NHC precatalyst to date, undergoing fast activation under both inert atmosphere and aerobic conditions. The catalyst system shows an excellent reactivity in amination of aryl halides, including challenging substrates, diamination and direct functionalization of pharmaceuticals, well superseding the classical IPr framework. The steric protection enables high reactivity under both inert and aerobic conditions. Specifically, the main advantage arises from the presence of a rigid bis(imino)acenaphtene) backbone that pushes the N-aryl substituents closer to palladium by the buttressing effect. This in turn permits for an improved stability of the metal complexes and higher overall performance. An additional effect is due to higher %V bur which directly increases reactivity in reductive elimination due to the steric interaction of the wingtip with the 2,7-hydrogens of the scaffold.[11] In this context, the BIAN scaffold addresses the typical decomposition pathway of NHC–metal complexes. Typically, NHC-metal complexes decompose by metal dissociation from the NHC-M complex, which is followed by carbene oxidation.[7] Steric protection increases the stability of NHC-metal complexes, where the ligands can adjust with flexible steric bulk protecting the metal, enabling stabilization of the active intermediates. The BIAN scaffold presents an increased steric protection due to the buttressing effect of N-aryl substituents. Overall, the catalyst platform represents a highly attractive approach to the use of N-heterocyclic carbenes for essential C–N bond formation with air-stable, well-defined Pd(II)–NHCs. [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 should be routinely utilized for the synthesis of C–N bonds to make valuable amines, where it replaces the most commonly deployed at present IPr (IPr = 1,3-bis(2,6-isopropyl)imidazol-2-ylidene). 2 Results and Discussion Our studies commenced with evaluation of the cross-coupling of 4-chlorotoluene with 4-toluidine (Table 1 ). We quickly established that CH3OK was the preferred base over t-BuOK, while other bases, such as K2CO3, DBU, DMAP were ineffective. Furthermore, increasing the temperature to 120 °C resulted in a quantitative conversion, while NaNH2 and TMSOK also emerged as promising bases for future studies. Examination of different solvents revealed that toluene is the preferred solvent, however, it is worth noting that sustainable 2-MeTHF can also be used as a reaction medium. Finally, decreasing the reaction time provided the optimal conditions for the coupling [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 (0.5 mol%), CH3OK, 3 equiv, toluene, 120 °C, 8 h]. With the optimized conditions in hand, the scope of the Buchwald-Hartwig amination using the acenaphthoimidazol-2-ylidene chloro dimer was next examined (Schemes 1–4 ). As shown, the scope of the reaction is excellent and encompasses various aromatic and aliphatic amines in the cross-coupling with aryl chlorides and, when more available, aryl bromides. As such, we first evaluated cross-coupling of various aryl halides with 4-toluidine as a representative aromatic amine (Scheme 1). This catalyst system is compatible with neutral (3a), sterically-hindered (3b, 3d), and electronically-deactivated (3c) halides. An array of electrophilic functional groups, such as cyano, acetyl or nitro are well-compatible, providing handles for further functionalization (3e–3i). Furthermore, heterocycles, such as benzothiophenes and pyridines (3j–3k) are well-tolerated. The catalyst can also be employed for benzylic aminations (3l). Finally, conjugated aromatic systems, such as naphthalenes or biaryls (3m–3o) can be readily employed, providing access to conjugated anilines that have found important applications in materials science. Next, the scope with morpholine as a model aliphatic amine was investigated (Scheme 2). As shown, the reaction uniformly afforded high yields across the range of substrates examined (3p–3ac). It is of particular interest that the catalyst system is amenable to the challenging diamination at all 3 positions of the ring (3ad–3af), attesting to the high efficiency of this system. Next, the scope of various amines was examined using 4-chlorotoluene as a model substrate (Scheme 3). As shown, a variety of amines, including aliphatic cyclic (3ag–3ah), 1° and 2° aliphatic (3ai–3aj), benzylic (3ak), chiral (3al), sterically-hindered aliphatic amines (3am) as well as challenging indoline and tetrahydroisoquinoline (3an–3ao) performed very well under the reaction conditions. Furthermore, a range of aromatic amines, including o-coordinating (3ap), 2° aromatic (3aq), electronically-neutral (3ar–3as), extremely sterically-hindered (3at–3au), electronically-differentiated (3av–3aw) as well as conjugated (3ax–3ay) amines coupled with high efficiency, showcasing the wide utility of this catalyst system. Intrigued by the excellent reactivity of the [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 catalyst, we probed its performance in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals and late-stage functionalization (Scheme 4). As shown, the synthesis of a small-molecule antiulcer drug lead, ABX464, which currently is in phase 3 of clinical development (4a), as well as an advanced intermediate in the synthesis of Brexpiprazole (schizophrenia treatment) (4b), and direct derivatization of an antihistaminic Desloratadine (4c–4d) proceeded uneventfully under the reaction conditions, demonstrating that this catalyst system is well-suitable for immediate applications in the pharmaceutical synthesis. To gain insight into the reactivity of [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, intermolecular competition studies were conducted (Scheme 5 ). As expected, electron-deficient chloroarenes are significantly more reactive (4-CF3:4-MeO, 90:10), while electron-rich anilines are inherently preferred (4-CH3:4-F, 70:30). These results are consistent with the established mechanism for Buchwald-Hartwig amination. Furthermore, the TON was determined for the Buchwald-Hartwig amination (Scheme 6 ) using [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 of 1,500 (0.05 mol%, 120 °C, 8 h) and 1,900 (0.025 mol%, 120 °C, 8 h), indicating high reactivity of the catalyst. Importantly, kinetic and comparative studies were performed (Fig. 2 and SI). The reactions were benchmarked against the most reactive to date imidazol-2-ylidene IPr dimer. All kinetic studies have been done in a side-by-side fashion using a standard bench-top set-up to enable full comparison between the tested conditions. As shown in Fig. 2, [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 gave favorable kinetic profile over the imidazol-2-ylidene dimer, [Pd(IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, under both inert and aerobic conditions. Furthermore, a series of comparative studies were conducted (Scheme 7-8 ) and demonstrated much higher efficiency than the IPr congener. Overall, the high reactivity of [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 is due to merging the advantages of palladium chloro dimers with the increased steric-hindrance around the metal by the acenaphthoimidazol-2-ylidene system. It is worthwhile to note that in general halo dimer palladium complexes of the type [Pd(NHC)(μ-X)X]2 are stable in solution in non-polar solvents.[9] These complexes dissociate to monomers under base conditions, which is followed by a reduction to a monoligated Pd(0)–NHC. However, it should be noted that in the presence of polar solvents, such as DMSO or acetonitrile, dimer dissociation occurs to give monomers. In general, the properties of these [Pd(NHC)(μ-X)X]2 precatalysts represent an optimal balance between the stability of Pd(II)-NHCs and their ease of activation to Pd(0)-NHCs, which results in the most active well-defined Pd(II)–NHC catalysts discovered to date. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, Buchwald-Hartwig amination is the single most important reaction technology for the synthesis of C–N bonds across chemical research, including pharmaceutical, fine chemical, advanced materials and a plethora of other fields of science. At present, the most reactive Pd(II)–NHC is the imidazol-2-ylidene based IPr chloro dimer, [Pd(NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2. In this manuscript, we reported air-stable, well-defined palladium–BIAN–NHC chloro dimer, [Pd(BIAN–NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, for Buchwald-Hartwig C–N cross-coupling reactions of aryl halides. The catalyst shows an excellent reactivity in Buchwald-Hartwig amination, including challenging substrates, diamination and direct functionalization of pharmaceuticals, well-superseding the classical IPr framework. The merger of the reactive properties of palladium chloro dimers, [Pd(IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, with the structural features of BIAN represents the most reactive Pd(II)–NHC precatalyst to date, undergoing fast activation under both inert atmosphere and aerobic conditions. [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 should be routinely utilized for the synthesis of C–N bonds to make valuable amines, where it replaces the most commonly deployed at present IPr (IPr = 1,3-bis(2,6-isopropyl)imidazol-2-ylidene). coredata.dc:description: Buchwald-Hartwig amination has become the fundamental method for constructing molecular architectures throughout chemical research, including the synthesis of pharmaceutical agents, natural products, fine chemicals, and advanced materials. Herein, we report air-stable, well-defined palladium–BIAN–NHC chloro dimer, [Pd(BIAN–NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, for Buchwald-Hartwig C–N cross-coupling reactions of aryl halides. This rapidly activating catalyst framework merges the reactive properties of palladium chloro dimers, [Pd(NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2, with the structural features of acenaphthoimidazol-2-ylidenes. [Pd(BIAN–NHC)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 is the most reactive Pd(II)–NHC precatalyst to date, undergoing fast activation under both inert atmosphere and aerobic conditions. The catalyst shows an excellent reactivity in Buchwald-Hartwig amination of aryl halides (59 examples), including challenging substrates, diamination and direct functionalization of pharmaceuticals. The steric protection enables high reactivity under both inert atmosphere and aerobic conditions. [Pd(BIAN–IPr)(μ-Cl)Cl]2 should be routinely utilized for the synthesis of C–N bonds to make valuable amines, where it replaces the most commonly deployed at present IPr (IPr = 1,3-bis(2,6-isopropyl)imidazol-2-ylidene).
